elements.content: In contrast to the in-situ generated 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate (4-ptz) ligand, the use of presynthesized 4-ptz led to the formation of a chiral cadmium coordination polymer with a rare μ5-bridging mode of the tetrazolate ligand. This type of tuning in the design of chiral coordination polymers is reported for the first time.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the in-situ generated 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate (4-ptz) ligand, the use of presynthesized 4-ptz led to the formation of a chiral cadmium coordination polymer with a rare μ5-bridging mode of the tetrazolate ligand. This type of tuning in the design of chiral coordination polymers is reported for the first time.

elements.content: In contrast to the in-situ generated 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate (4-ptz) ligand, the use of presynthesized 4-ptz led to the formation of a chiral cadmium coordination polymer with a rare μ5-bridging mode of the tetrazolate ligand. This type of tuning in the design of chiral coordination polymers is reported for the first time.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the in-situ generated 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate (4-ptz) ligand, the use of presynthesized 4-ptz led to the formation of a chiral cadmium coordination polymer with a rare μ5-bridging mode of the tetrazolate ligand. This type of tuning in the design of chiral coordination polymers is reported for the first time.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of chiral metal–organic coordination polymers continue to receive significant attention owing to their intriguing network topologies, and potential applications in the fields of separation, catalysis, magnetic, and optical materials. In addition to the well-known polycarboxylate moieties, N-heterocyclic bridging ligands such as imidazolate, pyrazolate, triazolate, and tetrazolate moieties have emerged as a unique class of building subunits. The unique coordination geometries, donor–acceptor polarity, and superexchange capacity of these N-heterocyclic groups provide versatile tools for the assembly of coordination polymers with a rich array of structural topologies and functions. In particular, these N-heterocyclic bridging ligands can be generated in situ according to the desired reaction conditions (ex. triazolate, tetrazolate) instead of using presynthesized N-heterocyclic ligands as starting reagents. As part of our ongoing efforts in the design and synthesis of functional crystalline materials, we were promoted to investigate the synthesis of a 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate (4-ptz) based coordination polymer possessing a high connecting secondary building unit and a novel network topology. We report herein on the design and synthesis of two new 4-ptz based coordination polymers: a chiral compound [Cd2Cl3(C6H4N5)] n (1) and an achiral species [Cd2Cl2(OH)(C6H4N5)(H2O)] n (2). One feature of this study is that a new μ5-bridging coordination mode of the 4-ptz ligand in compound 1 is observed for the first time (Scheme ), which is very different from others (μ2-, μ3-, μ4-bridging, Scheme ). Of particular interest is that the use of a presynthesized 4-ptz ligand or an in-situ generated 4-ptz under similar reaction conditions led to the formation of two distinct types of coordination polymers: one is chiral compound 1, the other is the achiral species 2 (Scheme ). This type of tuning in the design of chiral coordination polymers has never been reported.
elements.clean_text: The design and synthesis of chiral metal-organic coordination polymers continue to receive significant attention owing to their intriguing network topologies, and potential applications in the fields of separation, catalysis, magnetic, and optical materials. In addition to the well-known polycarboxylate moieties, N-heterocyclic bridging ligands such as imidazolate, pyrazolate, triazolate, and tetrazolate moieties have emerged as a unique class of building subunits. The unique coordination geometries, donor-acceptor polarity, and superexchange capacity of these N-heterocyclic groups provide versatile tools for the assembly of coordination polymers with a rich array of structural topologies and functions. In particular, these N-heterocyclic bridging ligands can be generated in situ according to the desired reaction conditions (ex. triazolate, tetrazolate) instead of using presynthesized N-heterocyclic ligands as starting reagents. As part of our ongoing efforts in the design and synthesis of functional crystalline materials, we were promoted to investigate the synthesis of a 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazolate (4-ptz) based coordination polymer possessing a high connecting secondary building unit and a novel network topology. We report herein on the design and synthesis of two new 4-ptz based coordination polymers: a chiral compound [Cd2Cl3(C6H4N5)] n  (1) and an achiral species [Cd2Cl2(OH)(C6H4N5)(H2O)] n  (2). One feature of this study is that a new μ5-bridging coordination mode of the 4-ptz ligand in compound 1 is observed for the first time (Scheme ), which is very different from others (μ2-, μ3-, μ4-bridging, Scheme ). Of particular interest is that the use of a presynthesized 4-ptz ligand or an in-situ generated 4-ptz under similar reaction conditions led to the formation of two distinct types of coordination polymers: one is chiral compound 1, the other is the achiral species 2 (Scheme ). This type of tuning in the design of chiral coordination polymers has never been reported.

elements.clean_text: 3  Assembly of Distinct Chiral and Achiral Coordination Polymers

elements.content: The self-assembly of CdCl2·2.5H2O with presynthesized 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole in water under hydrothermal conditions led to the formation of a homochiral compound [Cd2Cl3(C6H4N5)] n (1). Alternatively, the in situ self-assembly of CdCl2·2.5H2O with NaN3 and 4-cyanopyridine in water under similar hydrothermal conditions afforded the achiral compound [Cd2Cl2(OH)(C6H4N5)(H2O)] n (2) (Scheme ). Contrary to the synthesis of compound 1, in which the Cd2+ directly reacted with the 4-ptz ligand, the formation of compound 2 is very different, in the sense that it is achiral and the 4-ptz ligand is generated in situ during the self-assembly process.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly of CdCl2⋅2.5H2O with presynthesized 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole in water under hydrothermal conditions led to the formation of a homochiral compound [Cd2Cl3(C6H4N5)] n  (1). Alternatively, the in situ self-assembly of CdCl2⋅2.5H2O with NaN3 and 4-cyanopyridine in water under similar hydrothermal conditions afforded the achiral compound [Cd2Cl2(OH)(C6H4N5)(H2O)] n  (2) (Scheme ). Contrary to the synthesis of compound 1, in which the Cd2+ directly reacted with the 4-ptz ligand, the formation of compound 2 is very different, in the sense that it is achiral and the 4-ptz ligand is generated in situ during the self-assembly process.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed that [Cd2Cl3(C6H4N5)] n (1) crystallized in an orthorhombic unit cell with the chiral space group P212121. The crystallographic asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically distinct Cd2+ ions, three chloride anions, and a deprotonated pyridyltetrazolate ligand. It is noteworthy that the pyridyltetrazolate ligand serves as a rare μ5-bridged ligand connected to three Cd(1) ions and two Cd(2) ions (Figure ). This μ5-bridged coordination mode for the pyridyltetrazolate ligand is rare. The dihedral angle between the tetrazolate ring and pyridyl ring is 44.9(2)°. It is also noteworthy that the four Cd2+ ions are coordinated in a noncoplanar fashion toward the tetrazolate ring (Figure , inset).
elements.clean_text: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis showed that [Cd2Cl3(C6H4N5)] n  (1) crystallized in an orthorhombic unit cell with the chiral space group P212121. The crystallographic asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically distinct Cd2+ ions, three chloride anions, and a deprotonated pyridyltetrazolate ligand. It is noteworthy that the pyridyltetrazolate ligand serves as a rare μ5-bridged ligand connected to three Cd(1) ions and two Cd(2) ions (Figure ). This μ5-bridged coordination mode for the pyridyltetrazolate ligand is rare. The dihedral angle between the tetrazolate ring and pyridyl ring is 44.9(2)°. It is also noteworthy that the four Cd2+ ions are coordinated in a noncoplanar fashion toward the tetrazolate ring (Figure , inset).

elements.content: A rare μ5-bridged coordination mode of a pyridyltetrazolate ligand in 1. (Inset) A side-view of the pyridyltetrazolate ligand showing the noncoplanar coordination of four Cd2+ ions toward the tetrazolate ring.
elements.clean_text: 1  A rare μ5-bridged coordination mode of a pyridyltetrazolate ligand in 1. (Inset) A side-view of the pyridyltetrazolate ligand showing the noncoplanar coordination of four Cd2+ ions toward the tetrazolate ring.

elements.content: The cadmium ions are bridged by tetrazolate rings as well as chloride ions to form an edge- and corner-sharing octahedra, which are assembled into a one-dimensional (1-D) chain in a helical manner along the crystallographic 2-fold screw axis (21) in the b-direction (Figure a). This novel cadmium-tetrazolate coordination is believed to play an important role in the formation of the helical chain, which are arranged in a parallel fashion and are linked through tetrazolate rings and chloride ions, resulting in a two-dimensional (2-D) chiral layer along the ab-plane (Figure b). Furthermore, the pyridyl groups of the pyridyltetrazolate ligands serve as pillars to link adjacent chiral layers, leading to a layer-pillared chiral 3-D framework (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: The cadmium ions are bridged by tetrazolate rings as well as chloride ions to form an edge- and corner-sharing octahedra, which are assembled into a one-dimensional (1-D) chain in a helical manner along the crystallographic 2-fold screw axis (21) in the b-direction (Figure a). This novel cadmium-tetrazolate coordination is believed to play an important role in the formation of the helical chain, which are arranged in a parallel fashion and are linked through tetrazolate rings and chloride ions, resulting in a two-dimensional (2-D) chiral layer along the ab-plane (Figure b). Furthermore, the pyridyl groups of the pyridyltetrazolate ligands serve as pillars to link adjacent chiral layers, leading to a layer-pillared chiral 3-D framework (Figure c).

elements.content: (a) A view of the 1-D helical chain topology along the 2-fold screw axis in the b-direction; (b) top-view of the 2-D chiral layer formed by parallel assemblies of the helical chains along the ab-plane; (c) the 3-D layer-pillared chiral framework of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) A view of the 1-D helical chain topology along the 2-fold screw axis in the b-direction; (b) top-view of the 2-D chiral layer formed by parallel assemblies of the helical chains along the ab-plane; (c) the 3-D layer-pillared chiral framework of compound 1.

elements.content: Crystal structure analysis showed that compound [Cd2Cl2(OH)(C6H4N5)(H2O)] n (2) crystallized in an orthorhombic unit cell with the achiral space group Pbca. Unlike compound 1, the pyridyltetrazolate serves as a μ3-bridged ligand that is connected to two Cd(1) ion and one Cd(2) ion (Figure ). It is noteworthy that the dihedral angle between the tetrazolate ring and the pyridyl ring is only 12.7(2)°. The three Cd2+ ions are coordinated in a near-coplanar fashion toward the tetrazolate ring (Figure , inset).
elements.clean_text: Crystal structure analysis showed that compound [Cd2Cl2(OH)(C6H4N5)(H2O)] n  (2) crystallized in an orthorhombic unit cell with the achiral space group Pbca. Unlike compound 1, the pyridyltetrazolate serves as a μ3-bridged ligand that is connected to two Cd(1) ion and one Cd(2) ion (Figure ). It is noteworthy that the dihedral angle between the tetrazolate ring and the pyridyl ring is only 12.7(2)°. The three Cd2+ ions are coordinated in a near-coplanar fashion toward the tetrazolate ring (Figure , inset).

elements.content: A μ3-bridged coordination mode of the pyridyltetrazolate in 2. (Inset) A side-view of the pyridyltetrazolate ligand showing the near-coplanar coordination of two Cd2+ ions toward the tetrazolate ring.
elements.clean_text: 3  A μ3-bridged coordination mode of the pyridyltetrazolate in 2. (Inset) A side-view of the pyridyltetrazolate ligand showing the near-coplanar coordination of two Cd2+ ions toward the tetrazolate ring.

elements.content: For compound 2, the hexa-coordinated Cd(2) ions are bridged by hydroxide ions as well as chloride ions to form a one-dimensional edge-sharing octahedra, which is further assembled into a 2-D layer by Cd(1) octahedra as chain-to-chain linkers (Figure a). Furthermore, the pyridyltetrazolate ligands serve as pillars to link adjacent cadmium layers, leading to the formation of a layer-pillared achiral 3-D framework (Figure b,c). The π–π stacking interactions between adjacent pyridyl rings of the 4-ptz pillars are observed (Figure S2b, ).
elements.clean_text: For compound 2, the hexa-coordinated Cd(2) ions are bridged by hydroxide ions as well as chloride ions to form a one-dimensional edge-sharing octahedra, which is further assembled into a 2-D layer by Cd(1) octahedra as chain-to-chain linkers (Figure a). Furthermore, the pyridyltetrazolate ligands serve as pillars to link adjacent cadmium layers, leading to the formation of a layer-pillared achiral 3-D framework (Figure b,c). The π-π stacking interactions between adjacent pyridyl rings of the 4-ptz pillars are observed (Figure S2b, ).

elements.content: (a) A view of the 2-D layer topology along the ab-plane formed by the parallel assemblies of cadmium chains; (b) side-view of the 2-D layer; (c) the 3-D layer-pillared framework of compound 2.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) A view of the 2-D layer topology along the ab-plane formed by the parallel assemblies of cadmium chains; (b) side-view of the 2-D layer; (c) the 3-D layer-pillared framework of compound 2.

elements.content: The most striking observation of this study is the significant difference between the self-assembly of the presynthesized and in-situ generated pyridyltetrazolate ligand with the Cd ions. During the self-assembly of Cd2+ ions and the presynthesized pyridyltetrazolate ligand, the high Cd2+/4-ptz ratio might play a key role in the formation of the rare μ5-bridging mode of the pyridyltetrazolate moiety. It is most likely that the assembly of the high-distorted structure of the μ5-bridging pyridyltetrazolate moiety leads to the generation of helical chains, thereby forming the chiral framework 1. This is corroborated by the observation of a higher yield of the chiral compound 1 upon increasing the Cd2+/4-ptz ratio (Figure ). Optimization of the yields was achieved with a ratio of 4. In the presence of extremely high concentrations of metal ions, the subsequent control of the assembly reaction appears to be more difficult, leading to the variations in yields of 1. This is indeed a very intriguing observation and might be a useful approach in the design of chiral coordination frameworks.
elements.clean_text: The most striking observation of this study is the significant difference between the self-assembly of the presynthesized and in-situ generated pyridyltetrazolate ligand with the Cd ions. During the self-assembly of Cd2+ ions and the presynthesized pyridyltetrazolate ligand, the high Cd2+/4-ptz ratio might play a key role in the formation of the rare μ5-bridging mode of the pyridyltetrazolate moiety. It is most likely that the assembly of the high-distorted structure of the μ5-bridging pyridyltetrazolate moiety leads to the generation of helical chains, thereby forming the chiral framework 1. This is corroborated by the observation of a higher yield of the chiral compound 1 upon increasing the Cd2+/4-ptz ratio (Figure ). Optimization of the yields was achieved with a ratio of 4. In the presence of extremely high concentrations of metal ions, the subsequent control of the assembly reaction appears to be more difficult, leading to the variations in yields of 1. This is indeed a very intriguing observation and might be a useful approach in the design of chiral coordination frameworks.

elements.content: Yield of chiral compound 1 upon increasing the Cd2+/4-ptz ratio. Three experiments were performed for each M/L ratio.
elements.clean_text: 5  Yield of chiral compound 1 upon increasing the Cd2+/4-ptz ratio. Three experiments were performed for each M/L ratio.

elements.content: The achiral compound 2 was produced in the presence of 4-cyanopyridine and azide in a high molar ratio of metal ions. The μ3-bridging 4-ptz ligand was generated in situ during the reaction. The presence of more complicated reactants may interfere with the generation of the μ5-bridging mode of the pyridyltetrazolate, leading to the formation of the achiral compound 2.
elements.clean_text: The achiral compound 2 was produced in the presence of 4-cyanopyridine and azide in a high molar ratio of metal ions. The μ3-bridging 4-ptz ligand was generated in situ during the reaction. The presence of more complicated reactants may interfere with the generation of the μ5-bridging mode of the pyridyltetrazolate, leading to the formation of the achiral compound 2.

elements.content: The emission spectrum of compound 1 showed a peak at 380 nm that is attributed to an intraligand transition, as a similar emission at 360 nm for the 4-ptz ligand (Figure S3, ). For compound 1, no weight loss was observed before 440 °C from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and started to decompose over 440 °C (Figure S4, ). For compound 2, the results of TG analysis indicated that the framework remains stable up to 305 °C (Figure S5, ).
elements.clean_text: The emission spectrum of compound 1 showed a peak at 380 nm that is attributed to an intraligand transition, as a similar emission at 360 nm for the 4-ptz ligand (Figure S3, ). For compound 1, no weight loss was observed before 440 °C from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and started to decompose over 440 °C (Figure S4, ). For compound 2, the results of TG analysis indicated that the framework remains stable up to 305 °C (Figure S5, ).

elements.content: In conclusion, tuning the status of a tetrazolate ligand, either presynthesized or generated in situ, is a key step in the formation of the chiral coordination polymer with a rare μ5-bridging mode of the 4-ptz ligand. This observation is fascinating and this type of adaptation in the design of chiral coordination polymers has never been addressed to date.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, tuning the status of a tetrazolate ligand, either presynthesized or generated in situ, is a key step in the formation of the chiral coordination polymer with a rare μ5-bridging mode of the 4-ptz ligand. This observation is fascinating and this type of adaptation in the design of chiral coordination polymers has never been addressed to date.

elements.content: Experimental details, coordination environments of cadmium metal centers. TGA, PXRD, and IR data. X-ray crystallographic files for 1 and 2 in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Experimental details, coordination environments of cadmium metal centers. TGA, PXRD, and IR data. X-ray crystallographic files for 1 and 2 in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Presynthesized and In-Situ
Generated Tetrazolate Ligand
in the Design of Chiral Cadmium Coordination Polymer
